title: The great brain debate - Ted Altschuler

multiple-choice.question: In the 1861 debate between Ernest Aubertin and Pierre Gratiolet, Aubertin argued that speech and memory operated within the human brain using a model known as:

options.label: A
options.text: Distributed model

options.label: B
options.text: Localistic model

options.label: C
options.text: Connectionist model

options.label: D
options.text: Phrenology

multiple-choice.question: Which scientist challenged phrenology by selectively destroying parts of animal brains and observing which functions were lost?

options.label: A
options.text: Pierre Flourens

options.label: B
options.text: Jean-Baptiste Bouillaud

options.label: C
options.text: Karl Wernicke

options.label: D
options.text: Paul Broca

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what was the outcome of Paul Broca's 1861 autopsy of a patient who had lost the power to produce speech, but not the power to understand it?

options.label: A
options.text: It revealed highly localized frontal lobe damage, supporting the distributed model

options.label: B
options.text: It revealed highly localized frontal lobe damage, supporting the localistic model

options.label: C
options.text: It failed to identify any region associated with one specific function

options.label: D
options.text: It confirmed the connectionist model

multiple-choice.question: Which scientist built his own cortex map with 52 separate areas in 1909?

options.label: A
options.text: Korbinian Brodmann

options.label: B
options.text: Karl Wernicke

options.label: C
options.text: Eduard Hitzig

options.label: D
options.text: Gustav Fritsch

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is the current understanding of the brain, combining the ideas of Gratiolet and Aubertin?

options.label: A
options.text: The brain is a single, localized region responsible for all functions

options.label: B
options.text: The brain is a distributed network of regions working together to accomplish various functions

options.label: C
options.text: The brain is a connectionist model, where different regions work together to accomplish one process

options.label: D
options.text: The brain is a combination of localistic and connectionist models, with both models being used to understand cognition

title: How do scars form? - Sarthak Sinha

multiple-choice.question: Where are the most common places we see scars?

options.label: B
options.text: On our bones

options.label: C
options.text: On our skin

options.label: D
options.text: On our muscles

multiple-choice.question: What is the difference between healthy skin tissue and scar tissue under a microscope?

options.label: A
options.text: Healthy tissue has more collagen, while scar tissue has less

options.label: B
options.text: Healthy tissue has a basket-weave formation, while scar tissue has a single direction

options.label: C
options.text: Healthy tissue has a single direction, while scar tissue has a basket-weave formation

options.label: D
options.text: Healthy tissue has more ECM, while scar tissue has less

multiple-choice.question: What is fibrosis, and which organs are vulnerable to scarring?

options.label: A
options.text: Fibrosis is the overabundance of collagen in the skin, and the skin is the only organ vulnerable to scarring

options.label: B
options.text: Fibrosis is the presence of excessive fibrous connective tissue in an organ, and the skin, pancreas, lungs, and heart are vulnerable to scarring

options.label: C
options.text: Fibrosis is the overabundance of ECM in the skin, and the skin is the only organ vulnerable to scarring

options.label: D
options.text: Fibrosis is the overabundance of collagen in the pancreas, and the pancreas is the only organ vulnerable to scarring

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of keeping scar tissue in a moist environment?

options.label: A
options.text: To speed up the healing process

options.label: B
options.text: To make the scar tissue more durable

options.label: C
options.text: To maximize healing

options.label: D
options.text: To make the scar tissue less sensitive

options.label: A
options.text: They can develop new treatments for cancer

options.label: B
options.text: They can develop new treatments for heart problems

options.label: C
options.text: They can utilize multi-billion-dollar budgets more efficiently and help millions of people live better and healthier lives

options.label: D
options.text: They can develop new treatments for diabetes

title: Ideasthesia: How do ideas feel? - Danko NikoliÄ‡

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is the traditional model of our mental function?

options.label: A
options.text: The senses provide separate data to our brain which are then translated into the appropriate mental phenomena.

options.label: B
options.text: The brain first processes sensory information and then translates it into mental phenomena.

options.label: C
options.text: The senses and brain work together to create mental phenomena.

options.label: D
options.text: The brain is the only part of the mind-body problem.

multiple-choice.question: What is the phenomenon where people experience a direct connection between the parts of the brain responsible for sensory stimuli?

options.label: A
options.text: Synesthesia

options.label: B
options.text: Ideasthesia

options.label: C
options.text: Ideasthesia

options.label: D
options.text: Sensory overload

multiple-choice.question: What is ideasthesia, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: A direct connection between the parts of the brain responsible for sensory stimuli.

options.label: B
options.text: A connection between ideas and senses that underlies synesthesia.

options.label: C
options.text: A phenomenon where people experience a mixture of sensory inputs.

options.label: D
options.text: A type of sensory overload.

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of ideasthesia in action, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: People from different cultural backgrounds agreeing on the color of a shape.

options.label: B
options.text: People associating different sounds with different colors.

options.label: C
options.text: People recognizing the color red as warm and blue as cold.

options.label: D
options.text: People perceiving the shape "kiki" as spiky and the shape "bouba" as rounded.

multiple-choice.question: What are the implications of the ideasthesia model for our understanding of consciousness and the mind-body problem?

options.label: A
options.text: It suggests that the mind and body are separate entities.

options.label: B
options.text: It suggests that our sensory experiences are shaped by our conceptual understanding of the world.

options.label: C
options.text: It suggests that our senses and brain work together to create mental phenomena.

options.label: D
options.text: It suggests that the mind-body problem is still an open question.

title: Could comets be the source of life on Earth? - Justin Dowd

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: It causes comets to orbit the Sun.

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of amino acids found in comets?

options.label: A
options.text: They are the main active components in all living cells, but not essential for life.

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

multiple-choice.question: What is the relationship between comets and the formation of life on Earth?

options.label: A
options.text: Comets are responsible for the destruction of life on Earth.

options.label: B
options.text: Comets are the ultimate source of life on Earth, bringing amino acids and other organic molecules.

options.label: C
options.text: Comets have no relation to the formation of life on Earth.

options.label: D
options.text: Comets are a sign of death and the end of life on Earth.

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: The Kuiper Belt

options.label: C
options.text: The coma of a comet

options.label: D

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: It shows that comets are responsible for the destruction of life on Earth.

options.label: C
options.text: It suggests that life on Earth may not be unique and that other planets may also have life.

options.label: D
options.text: It has no relation to the formation of life on Earth.

title: How do germs spread (and why do they make us sick)? - Yannay Khaikin and Nicole Mideo

multiple-choice.question: What is the term used to describe the strategy a germ uses to get from one host to the next?

options.label: A
options.text: Virulence

options.label: B
options.text: Mode of transmission

options.label: C
options.text: Replication rate

options.label: D
options.text: Host mobility

options.label: A
options.text: Replicating within a host as quickly as possible

options.label: B
options.text: Transmitting to a new host as quickly as possible

options.label: C
options.text: Achieving a balance between replicating within a host and transmitting to a new host

options.label: D
options.text: Causing the most severe symptoms possible

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: Obstructing the transmission strategies of harmful germs through simple disease-control methods

options.label: D
options.text: Increasing the use of pesticides

options.label: B
options.text: The germs will remain the same in terms of virulence

options.label: C
options.text: The germs will evolve to be less virulent and cause milder symptoms

options.label: D
options.text: The germs will disappear entirely

title: If matter falls down, does antimatter fall up? - ChloÃ© Malbrunot

title: Cloudy climate change: How clouds affect Earth's temperature - Jasper Kirkby

multiple-choice.question: What is the projected global temperature rise if carbon dioxide concentrations in the atmosphere double, which is expected before the end of the 21st century?

options.label: A
options.text: 1.5 to 2.5 degrees Celsius

options.label: B
options.text: 2.5 to 4.5 degrees Celsius

options.label: C
options.text: 1.5 to 4.5 degrees Celsius

options.label: D
options.text: 4.5 to 6.5 degrees Celsius

multiple-choice.question: Why is it difficult to narrow down the estimate of 1.5 to 4.5 Celsius for a doubling of carbon dioxide?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the experiment at CERN is not yet complete.

options.label: B
options.text: Because we don't yet understand aerosols and clouds well enough.

options.label: C
options.text: Because the greenhouse gas concentrations are not well measured.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the radiative forcing is not precisely known.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main source of uncertainty in Earth's climate sensitivity?

options.label: A
options.text: The greenhouse gas forcings.

options.label: B
options.text: The radiative forcing of the present day climate relative to the pre-industrial climate.

options.label: C
options.text: The global temperature rise since 1750.

options.label: D
options.text: The amount of aerosol particles in clouds.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of the Cloud experiment at CERN?

options.label: A
options.text: To measure the effect of aerosols on clouds.

options.label: B
options.text: To determine Earth's climate sensitivity.

options.label: C
options.text: To investigate if galactic cosmic rays enhance the formation of aerosols in clouds.

options.label: D
options.text: To measure the greenhouse gas concentrations in the atmosphere.

multiple-choice.question: What are the two big questions that the Cloud experiment at CERN is addressing?

options.label: A
options.text: How cloudy was the pre-industrial climate, and how much have clouds changed due to human activities.

options.label: B
options.text: How much have clouds changed due to human activities, and could the puzzling observations of solar climate variability be explained by an influence of galactic cosmic rays on clouds.

options.label: C
options.text: Could the puzzling observations of solar climate variability be explained by an influence of galactic cosmic rays on clouds, and how cloudy was the pre-industrial climate.

options.label: D
options.text: How much have clouds changed due to human activities, and how cloudy was the pre-industrial climate.

options.label: D

options.label: D

options.text: Its exact speed and its exact temperature

options.label: C
options.text: Its exact position and its exact speed

options.text: Its exact momentum and its exact wavelength

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: C
options.text: If you want to reduce position uncertainty, you need to add more waves

options.label: D
